item.title: How 3D Printing Fuels STEAM Education
item.description:
How 3D Printing Fuels STEAM Education

Science, Technology, Education, Art, and Mathematics (STEAM) education has been a focus of development worldwide in recent years. Building upon conventional wisdom about STEM education, new research is inspiring teachers to add an artistic dimension to their math-and-science-based curricula.

item.title: One big question: Why can't we 3D print functioning organs today?
item.description:
One big question: Why can't we 3D print functioning organs today?

We recently reported on heart structures 3D-printed in a weightless environment. For the first of a regular new feature, we asked one of the company's chief scientist what was the single biggest impediment to having lab-grown organs available right now. Here's what he had to say.

item.title: MIT's shape-shifting 3D-printed objects could improve medicine and solar-power
item.description:
MIT's shape-shifting 3D-printed objects could improve medicine and solar-power

MIT and the Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) teamed up to create a new kind of structure that can "remember" its original shape, and return to that state even after being deformed or otherwise bent out of shape.

item.title: Library Used Its 3D Printer To Make Prosthetic Hand For Girl
item.description:
Library Used Its 3D Printer To Make Prosthetic Hand For Girl

A library has helped a 5-year-old girl start a new chapter in her life. Katelyn Vincik who was born without a fully formed left hand, had been on a waitlist for a functional prosthetic for more than a year. That was until Harris County Public Library in Texas made her one using its 3D printer.

item.title: www.3ders.org
item.description:
www.3ders.org

Aug 24, 2016 | By Benedict Shining 3D, a Chinese 3D printing company, is aiming to become a leader in the field of 3D bioprinting while simultaneously building China's 3D printing ecosystem. The company owns a 50% stake in Regenovo Biotech , the company behind the Regenovo 3D bioprinter.

item.title: The future of soft robotics: a 3D-printed, farting, gummy octopus
item.description:
The future of soft robotics: a 3D-printed, farting, gummy octopus

Even as some of us brace for the cephalopod uprising, octopuses have became the favorite animals of robotic engineers. And an adorable palm-sized octopus-robot, made by a group of Harvard researchers, might be the closest robots have ever gotten to the real eight-armed creature of the sea.

item.title: Researchers are now fabricating human tissues with a 3D printer
item.description:
Researchers are now fabricating human tissues with a 3D printer

In the modern medical world, to receive a skin, bone, organ, or muscle transplant, it has to be from another person. A donor has to supply you with the parts or, in the case of skin grafts, the patient themselves needs to have tissue removed.

item.title: Stratasys' latest moves show how quickly the 3D printing landscape is evolving
item.description:
Stratasys' latest moves show how quickly the 3D printing landscape is evolving

In some ways, the present-day 3D printing/additive manufacturing industry has much in common with the PC industry in the early-to-mid '80s. Penetration rates are still low, technologies and standards are rapidly evolving and figuring out who the winners and losers will be a decade from now is far from easy.

item.description:
Whimsical 3D-Printed Figurines : Wondermooi
